title: Review to find Labor's base voted against handouts
text:
Voters who were supposed to benefit the most from Labor's so-called "tax and spend" agenda deserted the party at the last election whereas those targeted by the policies tended to stick.

That is one of the findings believed to be contained in the report into Labor's shock May 18 election loss which is being finalised and will be handed to the party's National Executive on November 8.

Labor leader Anthony Albanese out on Sunday. He is expecting a review of the election result to conclude that Labor's loss was attributable to several factors including the unpopularity of predecessor Bill Shorten.

The six-member panel, led by former South Australian premier Jay Weatherill and former federal minister Craig Emerson, met in Canberra on Sunday to begin finalising their report.

It will conclude that Labor's loss was attributable to several factors including the unpopularity of leader Bill Shorten, a poor campaign and a policy agenda that was too large and left the party vulnerable to scare campaigns and attack.

One party source said of the latter that not all the policies were to blame but the amount of them and the size of the spending attached to them was a problem.
